statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.description: Predrag Stojakovic scored 27 points and all five Sacramento starters reached double figures Friday night as the Kings defeated the Minnesota Timberwolves 125-111.
article.headline: All five Kings' starters reach double figures

images.name: Stojakovic, Peja 011228 inline
images.caption: Predrag Stojakovic was a handful for all of the T-Wolves on Friday.

article.linkText: On balance, Kings cruise past Timberwolves
article.story:
SACRAMENTO, Calif. (AP) -- Good luck stopping the Sacramento Kings when their offense is going this good. The Minnesota Timberwolves, even with their gimmick defenses, couldn't do it. Predrag Stojakovic scored 27 points and all five Sacramento starters reached double figures in a 125-111 victory Friday night. The victory was their ninth straight at Arco Arena, improving the Kings (22-9) to an NBA-best 16-1 at home this season. The Kings shot 56 percent, committed only 10 turnovers and matched Minnesota in rebounds (38-38) to win their third straight game and avenge a 114-94 loss two weeks ago in Minnesota. "They beat us big time and we beat them the same way here," Kings center Vlade Divac said. There was no denying revenge was a motive for the Kings, who were embarrassed by the 61-35 rebounding edge the Timberwolves had in the previous game. Sacramento took the lead in the opening minutes and never trailed in scoring the most points against Minnesota this season. "We talked about how they manhandled us in Minnesota," Kings coach Rick Adelman said. "We wanted to respond. It was an important game for us. I could tell before the game we were ready to play." After watching a lead that was once 17 points dip to six early in the fourth quarter, five different players scored for the Kings in a 9-1 run that gave them a 106-92 lead with 6:51 remaining. The lead remained in double figures then rest of the game as the Kings improved to 6-2 with Chris Webber in the lineup. "Every time we made a run they stepped it up and we couldn't overcome it," Minnesota coach Flip Saunders said. Webber finished with 22 points and eight rebounds, Mike Bibby had 21 points and seven assists, Vlade Divac had 17 points and Doug Christie added 12. Scot Pollard scored 11 points. "The West is full of gunners and Sacramento is probably one of the best at that style of play," said Kevin Garnett, who guarded Stojakovic at times. "I was all over Peja, but he just made his shots." Wally Szczerbiak scored 21 of his 31 points in the second half for the Timberwolves. Rasho Nesterovic had 20 points and 10 rebounds, Garnett had 19 points and Chauncey Billups added 15 points and 11 rebounds. Garnett, who had 29 points and 24 rebounds in the previous game, shot just 8-of-22 and had eight boards. "I thought we did a good job on Garnett," Stojakovic said. "Hes so tough to stop." After trailing by 15 points at the half, Szczerbiak scored 10 points and Billups had eight as the Timberwolves outscored the Kings 35-29 in a wild third quarter, cutting the lead to 94-85 entering the final period. The Sacramento offense could not have run much smoother that it did in the first half. The Kings shot 61 percent, had only four turnovers and led 65-50. Stojakovic scored 14 points, while both Webber and Mike Bibby had 13. "We were aggressive and when we play like that we're tough to stop," Bibby said. "We have a lot of offensive firepower."

Game notes
The two teams combined for only eight first-half turnovers. ... The Kings made 13 of 14 free throws in the first half and finished ... 26-of-31. ... The Timberwolves started the third quarter making 10 of 12 shots.
